Award.AwardTitle: Combined Lab, Field, and Modeling Studies Aimed to Improve our Understanding of Sources of Ice Nuclei and their Impact on Western US Precipitation Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project builds upon the CalWater study conducted in 2009-2011 in California that investigated the impact of dust and bioparticles transported over long distances on clouds and precipitation processes over the Sierra Nevada mountain range. It is part of a larger project sponsored by the Department of Energy and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. This research seeks to gain a better understanding of the interactions between aerosols and clouds in the atmosphere and how these interactions influence precipitation processes. The results may be important for areas of California suffering from recent drought.

The project will address 3 questions: (1) Under which regimes do the ice nucleating properties of mineral dust, terrestrial, and marine biology origin impact mixed-phase, precipitating cloud systems? (2) How do the ice nuclei (IN) activity spectra differ between dust, bio-dust and bio-marine aerosols, and can these differences be adequately represented in numerical weather prediction models? And (3) Do scenarios of optimal IN number concentration, together with cloud microphysics and dynamic responses exist such that precipitation is enhanced?

Individual particle and IN mass spectra will be measured at a ground site using aerosol time-of-flight mass spectrometry (ATOFMS) and combined with data from other instruments on the ground and on the DOE aircraft, including a continuous flow diffusion chamber (CFDC), to provide information on the mixing state and sources of the aerosols. The Weather Research and Forecast model with aerosol speciated spectral bin microphysics (WRF-ASBM) will be run at cloud-resolving resolution and constrained by measured aerosol chemical type, IN concentrations, cloud water content and hydrometeor type measured by in-cloud imagery. The observations will be used to constrain and validate advanced numerical model simulations of aerosol cloud nucleation, hydrometeor-hydrometeor interaction, and precipitation. The results will have major implications for the field of aerosol-cloud interaction studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Atmospheric aerosols are comprised of small particles suspended in air which include dust, sea spray, and smoke. Aerosol particles profoundly impact our climate by scattering/absorbing sunlight and serving as cloud seeds.  Aerosol-cloud interactions represent the single largest uncertainty in our understanding of climate.

Both particle size and chemical composition affect a particle’s ability to form a cloud drop and ice nucleus. Only one in a million atmospheric particles will form an ice nucleus—with dust and bioparticles forming ice at the warmest temperatures. Overall, we have a very limited understanding of how different aerosol sources affect cloud formation, lifetime, and the location and intensity of precipitation. It is imperative we improve our understanding of how different aerosols influence clouds and precipitation processes as it will have tremendous consequences for our future climate as well as water resources.

This CalWater-2 project builds upon a previous project, CalWater, which was conducted in 2009-2011 in California. Both field studies were designed to probe the impact of different aerosol sources on clouds, precipitation, and climate in California. In aircraft measurements made during CalWater, in-situ cloud measurements of the composition of individual cloud condensation and ice nuclei demonstrated for the first time the profound impact long range transport of dust and bioparticles can have on precipitation processes over the Sierra Nevada mountain range. Specifically, we showed how meteorological conditions associated with Atmospheric Rivers are conducive to the transport of dust and bioparticles from as far away as Africa into the region, leading to seeding of mid-level mixed phase clouds and enhanced precipitation. We showed how the efficiency of precipitation processes can be strongly influenced by the presence of ice nuclei in mixed phase clouds.  Given the rarity of ice nuclei in the atmosphere, understanding the sources, conditions leading to their transport, and how frequently they seed and affect precipitation processes represented a major motivation for CalWater-2.

In CalWater-2, we expanded the sampling region to include the ocean to further investigate the role of local and long range transport of aerosols on precipitation processes using integrated aerosol, precipitation, meteorological, and modeling studies. Ground- (2015 and 2016) and aircraft-based (2015) field studies were conducted for 3 months from January through March to determine the sources and composition of aerosols seeding mixed phase clouds that control rainfall in the coastal mountains and the snowpack in the Sierra Nevada mountain range in California. In CalWater-2, we performed in-situ single particle aerosol time-of-flight mass spectrometry (ATOFMS) measurements of cloud residuals to determine the relative importance of local and long range transported dust, marine and terrestrial bioparticles, secondary marine-derived aerosols, and local pollution on cloud properties and precipitation over California. We also developed a hyphenated ATOFMS-CFDC instrument to directly measure the composition of individual particles that formed ice nuclei in ground-based measurements made at a coastal site at Bodega Bay, California.

Interestingly, aircraft measurements made in this study in 2015 showed the dominance of ocean-derived particles as cloud seeds in winter storm clouds, contrasting 2011 measurements which demonstrated the importance of long range transported dust and bioparticles. Notably the Pacific Ocean was relatively warm and biologically active in 2015 which appeared to play a major role in affecting the aerosols that actually seeded the clouds.  This warmer ocean also resulted in a meteorological condition referred to as “the blob” which diverted the long range transported dust to more northerly locations including Washington and Canada.

This interdisciplinary project trained a number of graduate students and postdocs, educating them in conducting field studies while learning a wide range of research including atmospheric chemistry, hydrology, meteorology, and analytical chemistry. The ground, aircraft, and modeling studies played a critical role in helping deconvolute the relative impacts of aerosol composition/source, ice nucleation, dynamics, and cloud microphysics on precipitation processes. The results from these investigations are being used to improve the treatment of aerosols in regional climate and weather forecast models.
